children.name: to get money or possessions from sb dishonestly
cheat
children.definition: lừa gạt
examples: He doesn’t trust car mechanics -- he thinks they’re all trying to cheat him.

children.name: cheat sb out of sth
examples: She says she was cheated out of $10,000 she paid to a modeling agency.
Cohen claimed that criminals posing as salesmen cheat Americans out of billions of dollars each year.

children.name: swindle
children.definition: to get money from a person or organization by cheating them, especially using clever and complicated methods: lừa đảo (tinh vi)
examples: He was jailed in 1992 for attempting to swindle the insurance company he worked for.
swindle[C noun] a well-planned and often complicated arrangement to cheat people: lừa đảo có quy mô
Young was convicted for his participation in a $2 million stock swindle.
The whole property development proposal was a swindle. They never intended to build anything.

children.name: swindle sb out of sth
examples: Investors have been swindled out of millions of pounds.

children.name: con
children.definition: to persuade sb to buy sth or to give you money by telling them lies: lừa đảo
examples: By the time she realized she had been conned, she had lost more than $3000.
con[C noun] [informal] a method or process of persuading sb to buy sth or to give you money by telling them lies
A lot of people gave money to the charity collectors, not realising it was a con.
con trick[UK]
She wanted me to visit a fortune-teller but I thought it was all a big con trick.

children.name: con sb out of sth
examples: The old lady was conned out of her life savings by a crooked insurance dealer.

children.name: con sth out of sb
examples: A man pretending to be a faith healer has conned around £20,000 out of desperate sick people.

children.name: con sb into doing sth
examples: She was too embarrassed to admit that they had conned her into buying 100 acres of worthless land.

children.name: fiddle
children.definition: to give false information or make dishonest changes to financial records, in order to get money or avoid paying money: làm sai lệch (sổ sách kế toán)
examples: My boss thinks I’ve been fiddling my travel expenses.
fiddle the books/ fiddle the accountschange a company’s financial records
The company secretary has been fiddling the books for years.
fiddle[C noun] [mainly UK informal] a situation in which people are cheated, especially in small ways over a long period of time: lừa gạt, lừa bịp
a tax fiddle
The firm realised some sort of fiddle was going on, but they had no idea how much they were losing.
work a fiddledo a fiddle
Managers don’t really get paid much here, but most of them are working a few fiddles.

children.name: Everyone suspected they wereon thefiddle
children.definition: cheating

children.name: defraud
children.definition: to get money from a company or organization, especially a very large one, by deceiving it: lừa gạt
examples: Trachtenberg is charged with attempting to defraud his business partner.

children.name: defraud sb (out) of sth
examples: Between them they defrauded the company out of hundreds of thousands of dollars.

children.name: fleece
children.definition: informal to get a lot of money from sb by tricking them: lừa đảo
examples: She fleeced him for everything he had.
Authorities estimate at least 300 elderly couples were fleeced in the scheme.

children.name: fleece sb of sth
examples: She estimates he fleeced her of about £50,000 by tricking her into buying fake antiques.

children.name: trick sb out of
children.definition: to get money or possessions from sb, by tricking or deceiving them:

children.name: lừa đảo
examples: Police are warning residents to be on their guard after two men tricked a pensioner out of several hundred pounds.
Megan was tricked out of her life savings by a smooth-talking handsome man who had promised to marry her.

children.name: you’ve been had U
children.definition: you’ve been had  use this to say that sb has been cheated but they do not realize it: bạn bị lừa rồi
examples: I hate to tell you this but you’ve been had. The antique clock you bought is a phoney.

children.name: do sb out of
children.definition: to cheat sb by not giving them money that they deserve or that they are owed: lừa gạt
examples: The way I see it, they’ve done me out of three weeks’ wages.
She’s convinced the sales assistant did her out of £15.

children.name: to trick sb and make them believe sth that is not true
trick
children.definition: to make sb believe sth that is not true, in order to get sth from them or make them do sth: lừa , đánh lừa
examples: I realized then that I had been tricked, but it was too late.
I’m not trying to trick you - just answer the question.

children.name: trick sb into doing sth
examples: The old man’s sons had tricked him into signing the papers.

children.name: trick sb out of sthtake something from someone by tricking them
examples: A man posing as an insurance agent tricked her out of thousands of dollars.

children.name: deceive
children.definition: to make sb who trusts you believe sth that is not true because it is useful for you if they believe it: lừa gạt
examples: This was a deliberate attempt to deceive the public.
Many children’s lies are unplanned and not actually designed to deceive.
All through the summer Paula was deceiving her husband while she was seeing another man.

children.name: deceive sb into doing sth
examples: Thousands of home buyers were deceived into buying homes at inflated prices.

children.name: deceive yourself
examples: If you think that everyone is happy with the plan, you’re deceiving yourself.

children.name: fool
children.definition: to make sb believe sth that is not true by using a clever but simple trick: đánh lừa , lừa phỉnh
examples: His hairpiece doesn’t fool anyone.

children.name: fool sb into doing sth
examples: They managed to fool the police into thinking they had left the country.

children.name: have sb fooled
examples: The brothers’ act had us all fooled.

children.name: you can’t fool mespoken
examples: You can’t fool me - I know he’s already given you the money.

children.name: fool yourself
examples: Maybe I was just fooling myself, but I really thought he liked me.

children.name: mislead
children.definition: to make people believe sth that is not true, by deliberately not giving them all the facts, or by saying sth that is only partly true: đánh lừa
examples: The report is a deliberate and obvious attempt to mislead.
They were accused of misleading customers about the nutritional value of their product.
He has admitted misleading the policeabouthis movements on the night of the murder.

children.name: mislead sb into doing sth
examples: Agents are accused of misleading clients into signing up for savings plans that were actually insurance policies.

children.name: con
children.definition: to trick sb:
examples: He was trying to con me, and I knew it.

children.name: con sb into doing sth
examples: They conned the school district into buying the property.

children.name: con sb out of sthtake sth from sb by tricking them
examples: She conned me out of $50.

children.name: set sb up
children.definition: to trick sb into doing sth that they will be punished for or embarrassed by :
examples: He said, following his arrest last fall, that the FBI had set him up.
Terry and Donald think I set them up, but it’s all a big misunderstanding.
They claimed that they weren't selling drugs, but that they'd been set up by the police.

children.name: put one over on
children.definition: sb informal to deceive sb, especially sb who is cleverer than you are, or sb who is not easily deceived:
examples: That’s the last time he puts one over on me!
Lawyers claim that the tobacco industry, by failing to tell everything it knew about smoking, was putting one over on its customers.

children.name: lead sb on
children.definition: to make sb believe you and trust you, especially by making them think you are romantically interested in them:
examples: I can’t tell if he really cares about me or if he’s just leading me on?
I didn’t mean to lead Cassie on, but I didn’t want to hurt her feelings either.
All that time she'd been leading him on (= pretending she liked him) , but she was only interested in his money.

children.name: pull the wool over sb’s eyes
children.definition: informal to deceive sb, usually by hiding some facts or information:
examples: Don’t try and pull the wool over my eyes - I can tell you’ve been smoking.
The politicians are just trying to pull the wool over voters’ eyes again.

children.name: take sb for a ride
children.definition: informal to deceive sb, especially so that you can get their money:
examples: I’d already given him £50 when I realized he was taking me for a ride.
After the deal was signed, I felt like I’d been taken for a ride.
Be careful or he'll take you for a ride.

children.name: double-cross
children.definition: to cheat sb you pretended to be helping or working with, especially by helping their enemies: chơi hai mặt, chơi trò hai mang
examples: I’m warning you - if you double-cross me, I’ll kill you.
Harry and Danny double-crossed the gang and escaped with all the money.

children.name: dupe
children.definition: informal to trick or deceive sb, especially so that they become involved in sb else’s dishonest activity without realizing it:
examples: The spies duped government and military officials alike.
dupe sb into doing sth
The perpetrators of the hoax managed to dupe respectable journalists into printing their story
The girls were duped by drug smugglersintocarrying heroin for them.

children.name: take in
children.definition: take sbin

children.name: to cause sb to believe sth which is not true, or to trick or deceive someone
examples: I can't believe she was taken in by him.

children.name: trick
children.definition: a clever plan designed to make sb believe sth that you want them to believe, or do sth that you want them to do: thủ thuật ,mánh khóe
examples: He pretended to be sick as a trick to get her to visit him.
Don’t send her any money - it might be a trick.

children.name: deception
children.definition: sth that is said or done with the deliberate intention of deceiving people:trò lừa dối, mưu mẹo gian dối, mánh khoé lừa bịp
examples: Ann quickly saw through his lies and deceptions.
What began as a misunderstanding quickly became a deliberate deception on the part of the network.

children.name: ruse
children.definition: a trick, especially one that is amusing and not very serious: mưu mẹo, thủ đoạn
examples: It was just a ruse to get what I wanted!
She asked to use the telephone as a ruse to enter the house.

children.name: hoax
children.definition: a false warning about sth dangerous, given especially to sb in an official position, for example the police: đánh lừa; chơi khăm; chơi xỏ
examples: To everybody’s great relief, the bomb scare turned out to be a hoax.
I got an email about another computer virus, but I’m pretty sure it’s just a hoax.
The bomb threat turned out to be a hoax.
He'd made a hoaxcallclaiming to be the President.

children.name: congame
children.definition: / con informal a trick to get sb’s money or make sb do sth:
examples: The two men were involved in an elaborate con to cheat investors out of their money.
Senior citizens are usually easy targets for con games.

children.name: put-up job
children.definition: informal when sth that happens is not what it seems to be, and is really an attempt to deceive people: sự gài bẫy; cú-mông-tê
examples: Journalists suspected that the kidnapping was a put-up job.
The demonstration was a put-up job, organized by the authorities so they could arrest the cult leaders.
The scheme looked like a good investment, but it turned out that the whole thing was a put-up job.

children.name: decoy
children.definition: a person or thing that is used to trick sb by taking their attention away from an illegal or criminal act: mồi, bả
examples: You act as a decoy and we’ll sneak out the back.
The burglars started the fire as a decoy so that they could escape from police.

children.name: to be tricked or deceived by sb
be tricked
children.definition: / deceived
examples: He knew he’d been tricked, but it was too late to do anything.

children.name: be tricked/ deceived by
examples: Don’t feel bad - you weren’t the only one who was deceived by his lies.

children.name: be taken in
children.definition: take sbin

children.name: fall for
children.definition: sth  to stupidly believe sth that is untrue and is intended to deceive you:
examples: Doug is too clever to fall for a story like that!
She completely fell for his nonsense about being rich and famous.
He told me he owned a mansion in Spain and I fell for it.

children.name: be fooled
children.definition: to be deceived by sb’s behaviour, words, or appearance, especially when the result is not serious:
examples: Don’t let yourself be fooled - she’s not as nice as she seems.

children.name: be fooled by
examples: A lot of people were fooled by what he said, but I was sure he was lying.

children.name: be set up
children.definition: to be tricked into doing sth that results in you being punished or embarrassed
examples: I’m innocent! I was set up!

children.name: be set up by
examples: The young man’s claim that he had been set up by the police was eventually supported by several witnesses.

children.name: be duped
children.definition: to be deceived by sb, especially so that you become involved in their dishonest activity without realizing it:
examples: When the police arrived to arrest her, she realized she had been duped.

children.name: be duped by
examples: Richie couldn’t believe he had been set up and duped by his friends.

children.name: dupe
children.definition: sb who is tricked by sb else, especially so that they become involved in the other person’s dishonest plans without realizing it:
examples: Investigators believe Dailey was a dupe for international drug smugglers.

children.name: unwitting dupe
examples: Some portray the family as unwitting dupes of conspiracy theorists.

children.name: sucker
children.definition: sb who believes everything they are told, even when it is clearly not true:gã khờ; người dễ bị lừa
examples: I know I’m a sucker. I’ll give $10 to anyone who tells me they’re hungry or wants a cup of coffee.
Some poor suckers had paid more than three times what they should have for the tickets.

children.name: mug
children.definition: sb who is easily deceived, especially so that they do much more or give much more than is fair or reasonable: người dễ bị lừa
examples: He’s asked me to work over the weekend again - he must think I’m some kind of mug.
Don’t be a mug! That picture’s not worth as much as that!

children.name: cheat
children.definition: /cheater  người lừa đảo, kẻ gian lận
examples: Don’t pretend you can’t afford to pay me that money back -- you’re nothing but a cheat and a liar!
My grandmother thinks all car salesmen are cheats.
I’ll never play cards with you again, you cheater!
Trouble broke out in the match when one of the players called a member of the other team a cheat.

children.name: quack
children.definition: a dishonest person who pretends to be a doctor who can cure diseases: thầy lang
examples: Larry paid some quack over a thousand dollars to cure his insomnia.
That quack doesn’t know anything about treating heart disease.

children.name: shyster
children.definition: a dishonest person, especially a lawyer:
examples: Their lawyer is a shyster who would do anything to win a case.
Once the shysters get involved, you can be sure we’ll end up in court.

children.name: snake-oil salesman
children.definition: / peddler  sb who deceives people by persuading them to accept false information, solutions etc that are not effective: con buôn giả tạo
examples: Critics have called the Senator a smooth-talking snake-oil peddler.
Latenight TV is full of snake-oil salesmen offering get-rich-quick schemes.

children.name: when sb tricks or deceives sb
deception
children.definition: the act of deceiving sb, especially by telling them lies:
examples: I’m sure many businessmen use some form of deception, at times, to achieve their objectives.
She was stunned by the lies and deception her husband had used to hide his affairs.
He was found guilty of obtaining money by deception.

children.name: deceit
children.definition: the act of deceiving sb - use this to show strong disapproval:
examples: His political opponents have accused him of corruption and deceit.
He now found himself in a world where deceit was accepted, even expected.

children.name: set up
children.definition: a situation in which sb is tricked into doing sth that results in them being punished:
examples: Is this some kind of a set up? Why should I believe you?
The whole thing was a set up to get Burley to confess.

children.name: trickery
children.definition: the use of clever plans or actions to deceive sb
examples: It was a piece of political trickery that enraged the opposition.
He’s managed to get as far as he has through slick talking and trickery.
The government, he said, had resorted to political trickery in their attempts to retain power.

children.name: make a fool of sb
children.definition: make a fool ofsb
examples: to trick someone or make them appear stupid in some way

children.name: play games
children.definition: to try to deceive someone
examples: _Don't play gameswithme!
